title: Lumber Prices Hit 2025 Low
description:
Lumber prices, which shed more than 20% in August, have continued to fall to start September, hitting their lowest price this year thanks to a glut of wood that was piled up ahead of a big increase in duties on Canadian imports.
"There has clearly been a speculative inventory accumulation at every
content:
Lumber prices, which shed more than 20% in August, have continued to fall to start September, hitting their lowest price this year thanks to a glut of wood that was piled up ahead of a big increase in duties on Canadian imports. "There has clearly been a speculative inventory accumulation at every level from mills to single location lumber dealers," said Matt Layman, a market analyst and consultant who publishes Layman’s Lumber Guide "For the first time in my 40-plus year career there is indeed a wall of wood that must be liquidated."

Wood buyers stocked up ahead of higher duties on Canadian lumber imports, which took effect last month. (Landon Speers for WSJ)

As with many raw materials, the lumber market has been whipsawed by President Trump's tariff threats. The White House is studying tariffs on imported lumber in the name of national security, as it has with steel, aluminum and copper products.
summary: Lumber prices have dropped significantly since August, with a surge in demand due to a shortage of wood. This comes ahead of a significant increase in duties on Canadian imports. The White House is considering imposing tariffs on imported lumber in the name of national security. The market analyst, Matt Layman, noted that there has been a speculative inventory accumulation at all levels of the industry.
shortSummary: Lumber prices dropped significantly in August due to a significant glut, prompting concerns about consumer protection and potential US-based retaliation.
argos_summary: Lumber prices fell over 20% in August and continued to drop into September, reaching their lowest level this year. The decline is driven by a glut of wood stockpiled ahead of a significant increase in duties on Canadian lumber imports. Speculative inventory buildup across mills and dealers has exacerbated the oversupply. The U.S. government is also considering tariffs on imported lumber under national security pretexts, adding further uncertainty to the market.
